title: How to Install a Basement Toilet

steps.headline: Place the macerator unit so it will be behind the toilet's location.
steps.description: The unit will connect to the back of the macerating toilet.

steps.headline: Connect a discharge pipe to the macerator's drainpipe.
Connect the macerator unit to an existing vent stack inside the house with PVC vent piping.
Place the toilet in its desired position in the basement.
steps.description: Mark the mounting holes for the toilet on the floor.

steps.headline: Move the toilet away.
steps.description: Drill pilot holes into the basement floor.

steps.headline: Use 2 brass screws to secure the toilet in place over the holes.
Connect the macerator unit to the back of the toilet.
steps.description: An accordion-like gasket may work as a connector. Secure the connection with a stainless steel clamp tightened with the nut driver.

steps.headline: Connect the basement toilet with the water-supply line.
Plug the unit into a GFCI outlet.

text:
Place the macerator unit so it will be behind the toilet's location. The unit will connect to the back of the macerating toilet. Connect a discharge pipe to the macerator's drainpipe. The discharge pipe can feed into a piping system and connect with the house's main drainage system to get rid of waste. Fit the macerator unit manufacturer's discharge adapter onto the discharge pipe and the macerator's outlet port to connect them. The port is on top of the macerator unit. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/53/Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/53/Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Tighten the discharge adapter with the nut driver so it is secure. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cc/Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-2Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cc/Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-2Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} A gate valve is recommended on the discharge line near the macerator's outlet. This will come in handy if the macerator needs to be serviced. Without the macerator in place there won't be anything to hold the waste in the vertical run of the discharge line. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d3/Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-2Bullet3.jpg/v4-460px-Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-2Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d3/Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-2Bullet3.jpg/v4-760px-Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-2Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Connect the macerator unit to an existing vent stack inside the house with PVC vent piping. This provides necessary ventilation. You may need to apply PVC pipe primer and cement before fitting the PVC piping to the vent stack and macerator unit. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a2/Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-3Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a2/Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-3Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} A new vent line may be ran if an existing vent stack is inaccessible. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d4/Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-3Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-3Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d4/Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-3Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-3Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Place the toilet in its desired position in the basement. Mark the mounting holes for the toilet on the floor. Move the toilet away. Drill pilot holes into the basement floor. Use 2 brass screws to secure the toilet in place over the holes. Connect the macerator unit to the back of the toilet. An accordion-like gasket may work as a connector. Secure the connection with a stainless steel clamp tightened with the nut driver. Connect the basement toilet with the water-supply line. Open the water shut-off valve. Plug the unit into a GFCI outlet. (Ground Fault Circuit Interrupter) Flush the toilet. Check for any leaks.
sentences: Place the macerator unit so it will be behind the toilet's location.
The unit will connect to the back of the macerating toilet.
Connect a discharge pipe to the macerator's drainpipe.
The discharge pipe can feed into a piping system and connect with the house's main drainage system to get rid of waste.
Fit the macerator unit manufacturer's discharge adapter onto the discharge pipe and the macerator's outlet port to connect them.
The port is on top of the macerator unit.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/53\/Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-2Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/53\/Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-2Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Tighten the discharge adapter with the nut driver so it is secure.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/cc\/Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-2Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/cc\/Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-2Bullet2.jpg\/v4-760px-Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} A gate valve is recommended on the discharge line near the macerator's outlet.
This will come in handy if the macerator needs to be serviced.
Without the macerator in place there won't be anything to hold the waste in the vertical run of the discharge line.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/d3\/Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-2Bullet3.jpg\/v4-460px-Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-2Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/d3\/Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-2Bullet3.jpg\/v4-760px-Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-2Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Connect the macerator unit to an existing vent stack inside the house with PVC vent piping.
This provides necessary ventilation.
You may need to apply PVC pipe primer and cement before fitting the PVC piping to the vent stack and macerator unit.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a2\/Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a2\/Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} A new vent line may be ran if an existing vent stack is inaccessible.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/d4\/Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-3Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-3Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/d4\/Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-3Bullet2.jpg\/v4-760px-Install-a-Basement-Toilet-Step-3Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Place the toilet in its desired position in the basement.
Mark the mounting holes for the toilet on the floor.
Move the toilet away.
Drill pilot holes into the basement floor.
Use 2 brass screws to secure the toilet in place over the holes.
Connect the macerator unit to the back of the toilet.
An accordion-like gasket may work as a connector.
Secure the connection with a stainless steel clamp tightened with the nut driver.
Connect the basement toilet with the water-supply line.
Open the water shut-off valve.
Plug the unit into a GFCI outlet.
(Ground Fault Circuit Interrupter) Flush the toilet.
Check for any leaks.
